cases.caseName: Li Shuk Man v Ho Wai Ling Rebecca t/a Windsor Sauna
cases.annotation: Directly interprets the s.2 definitions of 'wages' and 'tips and service charges.' The court examines at length whether tips paid to sauna workers were 'recognised by the employer as part of the employee's wages' under the s.2 definition. The judgment sets out the full statutory text of both definitions and turns on whether the employer's conduct satisfied the recognition requirement.

cases.caseName: Wong Pui Tuen Kenny v Crown Motors Ltd
cases.annotation: Interprets the s.2(1) definition of 'wages', specifically whether commissions paid by a third party fall within the statutory meaning. The court quotes the full s.2(1) definition and analyses whether 'payable to an employee in respect of work done or to be done under his contract of employment' requires payment by the employer or can extend to third-party payments, holding the definition is wide enough to cover third-party payments provided they arise under the contract of employment.

cases.caseName: Zhu Li v Mayer Brown JSM
cases.annotation: Applies the s.2 definition of 'contract of employment' to determine whether a working relationship fell under the Employment Ordinance. The Court of Appeal quotes s.2's definition ('any agreement whether in writing or oral, express or implied, whereby one person agrees to employ another and that other agrees to serve his employer as an employee') and uses it alongside s.4 to establish that the plaintiff's claims necessarily framed the relationship as one of employment.

cases.caseName: Archer v The Hong Kong Channel Ltd
cases.annotation: Interprets the s.2 definition of 'relevant date' for calculating long service payment eligibility. The Court of Appeal examined the definition: 'where an employee's contract of employment is terminated by payment in lieu of notice in accordance with section 7, the date up to which such wages are calculated.' This definition was decisive — it shifted the end date of employment and determined whether the employee had completed the requisite 5 years of service for long service payment under s.31R.

cases.caseName: Zhu Li v Mayer Brown JSM
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal quotes s.4 and the s.2 definition of 'contract of employment,' analyzing whether the plaintiff had sufficiently pleaded an employment relationship to engage the Employment Ordinance. Establishes that s.4(1) operates as the gateway provision — the Ordinance only applies where there is a genuine employment relationship under a contract of employment.

cases.caseName: Law Kwai Wing v Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority
cases.annotation: Directly engages s.4(2) — the exclusion provision for seafarers. The applicant was employed under the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) Ordinance and was therefore an 'excluded person' under s.4(2). Because the MPFSO defines 'employee' by reference to Cap 57 'other than a person excluded by section 4(2),' the applicant fell outside the MPF scheme. Illustrates how s.4(2) exclusions affect other statutory regimes that cross-reference the Employment Ordinance.

cases.caseName: Fong Chak Kwan v Ascentic Limited
cases.annotation: Quotes both the s.2(1) definition of 'employee' (which expressly refers to s.4: 'employee means an employee to whom, by virtue of section 4, this Ordinance applies') and s.4(1) itself, in the context of determining employee status for purposes of the Employees' Compensation Ordinance. Shows how s.4 operates as the definitional anchor for 'employee' status across multiple Hong Kong employment statutes.

sections.titleZh: 以通知終止合約的情況

cases.caseName: Tadjudin Sunny v Bank of America, National Association
cases.annotation: The court conducted a full trial on whether implied anti-avoidance terms could be read into an employment contract governed by ss.6-7 of the Employment Ordinance. The Bank argued that any implied term restricting its right to terminate would be inconsistent with the unqualified statutory right to dismiss under ss.6 and 7. To J held that the implied anti-avoidance term (preventing dismissal to avoid paying a bonus) was not inconsistent with ss.6-7, as the statutory provisions merely prescribe the mechanics of termination (notice or payment in lieu) and do not confer an absolute right to dismiss for any purpose.

cases.caseName: Tadjudin Sunny v Bank of America, National Association
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal reversed the CFI's interlocutory strike-out of implied term claims. Suffiad J held that in a developing area of law such as implied anti-avoidance terms in employment contracts, it was inappropriate to determine at an interlocutory stage whether such terms were inconsistent with the statutory right to terminate under ss.6 and 7. The court emphasised that the question of whether implied terms can co-exist with the statutory termination rights under the Ordinance was fact-sensitive and should be resolved at trial.

cases.caseName: Tadjudin Sunny v Bank of America, National Association
cases.annotation: Chu J struck out the plaintiff's implied term claims at an interlocutory stage, holding that ss.6 and 7 of the Employment Ordinance confer upon the employer an unqualified statutory right to terminate without cause, and that no implied term (including the implied term of mutual trust and confidence) could cut down that clear statutory right. The judge followed Sun Zhongguo v BOC Group Ltd [2003] 2 HKC 239 and the House of Lords decision in Johnson v Unisys Ltd. This decision was later reversed on appeal.

cases.caseName: Lui Lin Kam & Others v Nice Creation Development Ltd
cases.annotation: The leading authority on continuous contracts. Tang JA held that a break of working less than 18 hours within one week is sufficient to break the continuity of employment under Schedule 1. Confirmed that even a casual employee paid daily can be deemed to be under a continuous contract if they work 18+ hours per week for 4+ consecutive weeks. Extensively cited by virtually all subsequent decisions on continuous contracts.

cases.caseName: David Hot Blocking Press Ltd v Ho King Yam
cases.annotation: An employer dismissed an employee just before the 1986 long service payment legislation took effect, then re-hired them, attempting to break continuity. The court held that the statutory concept of 'continuous contract' under s.3 and the First Schedule cannot be defeated by such a scheme. Conducted a detailed analysis of the week-counting mechanism and the 18-hour threshold in the First Schedule.

cases.caseName: Fong Anne v Hong Kong Adventist Hospital
cases.annotation: A casual dental hygienist with varying weekly hours. Following Lui Lin Kam (CA), the court held that even a one-week break of less than 18 hours, if a 'real break,' is sufficient to break continuity. Provides detailed analysis of how to count hours under the First Schedule, including hours where the employee is absent by mutual arrangement or trade custom. Particularly useful for understanding continuous contract thresholds for part-time workers.

cases.caseName: Sun Hiu Lan & Others v Leung King Catering Holding Ltd
cases.annotation: Restaurant employees were repeatedly forced to sign fixed-term contracts and 'voluntary resignation' letters, with the employer attempting to break continuity. The court emphasized that 'continuous employment' and 'continuous contract' are legal terms of art defined by reference to the First Schedule's 4-week/18-hour rule and cannot be replaced by common-sense notions of 'work seniority.'

cases.caseName: Luen Hing Engineering Co v Lam Cho Kwan & Others
cases.annotation: Examines whether engineering workers were employed on continuous contracts, setting out s.3, the First Schedule definition, and the interplay with ss.5 and 6. Confirms the onus provision in s.3(2): in any dispute, the burden of proving the contract is NOT a continuous contract falls on the employer.

sections.titleEn: Termination of contract by payment in lieu of notice
sections.titleZh: 以代通知金終止合約的情況

cases.caseName: Kao Lee & Yip v Lau Wing
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal directly construed s.7(1), holding that 'agreeing to pay' wages in lieu of notice means the terminating party's unilateral undertaking to pay, not a bilateral agreement between employer and employee. The court also interpreted s.7(2), confirming that an employee may give notice under s.6 and then shorten the notice period by paying wages in lieu for the remaining period under s.7(2). Two solicitors successfully relied on ss.6 and 7 to leave their firm with one month's notice plus payment in lieu for the remaining two months.

cases.caseName: Thomas Vincent v South China Morning Post Publishers Ltd
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal set out the framework for termination under the Employment Ordinance: s.6 gives both employer and employee the right to terminate by giving notice; s.7 gives both the right to terminate by payment of wages in lieu of notice. The court emphasised that the only situation the Ordinance refers to as 'wrongful' termination is under s.8A — where a party terminates without notice or payment in lieu when either was required. Termination with proper notice or payment in lieu under ss.6-7 is lawful, even if the employee considers the reason unfair.

cases.caseName: Lam Siu Wai v Equal Opportunities Commission
cases.annotation: The court considered whether an employer's reliance on s.7 to terminate without cause could nonetheless constitute a breach of contract. The Labour Tribunal had held that s.7 only establishes a 'mode of termination' and does not override the employer's duty not to breach express or implied terms of the employment contract. The EOC had terminated Lam's employment under s.7 with payment in lieu but the termination was found to breach contractual terms.

cases.caseName: Cheung Chi Keung v Hospital Authority
cases.annotation: Deputy Judge To explained that the statutory right to terminate under ss.6 and 7 is available to both employer and employee, and may be modified by contract to the extent the contractual terms are not inconsistent with the statutory right. For example, parties may agree to a notice period longer than the statutory minimum of seven days, or specify that notice must be in writing. The Hospital Authority had contractually required three months' notice, which was upheld as a valid modification of the statutory right.

sections.titleEn: Termination of contract without notice by employer
sections.titleZh: 僱主不給予通知而終止合約的情況

cases.caseName: Law Ying Chung v Lo Chun-kie t/a Koon Hing Plastic Factory
cases.annotation: Court of Appeal authority on s.9(1)(a)(ii) misconduct and s.9(1)(a)(iv) habitual neglect. Citing Ribeiro PJ's 'The Law and Practice of the Labour Tribunal', the Court endorsed that summary dismissal is a 'strong measure to be justified only in exceptional circumstances' and must involve misconduct going 'to the root of the contract so as to indicate an unwillingness to continue to be bound upon the original terms.' On habitual neglect under s.9(1)(a)(iv), the court affirmed the test that neglect must be both substantial and habitual.

cases.caseName: Tsang Tak Chi v China Wall Ltd
cases.annotation: A landmark s.9 case establishing that summary dismissal for a single act of misconduct is justified only in very exceptional circumstances, and that the court may balance the impact of summary dismissal on the employee with the effect of the misconduct on the employer. The court described summary dismissal as the 'capital punishment' of employment law, as the employee is deprived of all statutory protection under the Employment Ordinance.

cases.caseName: Li Shuk Man v Ho Wai Ling Rebecca t/a Windsor Sauna
cases.annotation: Leading authority on the burden of proof in s.9 summary dismissal cases. The court held that once the employee proves summary dismissal without notice, the burden shifts to the employer to justify the dismissal under s.9. Chung J reasoned that if an employer wants to invoke s.9 as a defence, the general rule puts the burden on the party asserting the defence. This clarified conflicting earlier authorities on burden allocation.

cases.caseName: Ng Ai Kheng Jasmine v The Open University of Hong Kong
cases.annotation: Held that disciplinary procedures are purely optional before invoking s.9 — there is no requirement to subject the employee to internal disciplinary proceedings before summary dismissal. On dishonesty, the court noted the degree of dishonesty capable of giving rise to dismissal under s.9(1)(a)(iii) is 'very low', as the statute separately identifies fraud or dishonesty as a standalone ground for summary dismissal.

cases.caseName: Keung Man Lan v Oceanic Universal Garment Manufacturers Co Ltd
cases.annotation: Applied s.9 to persistent lateness, holding that workers who continued to be late despite notices to desist were lawfully dismissed under s.9 for wilful disobedience and/or habitual neglect of duties. The court established that the employer's true motive is irrelevant to whether the s.9 ground is made out, and that an employer is not precluded from dismissing for continuing breaches merely because it had previously forborne from exercising that right.

sections.titleEn: Termination of contract without notice by employee
sections.titleZh: 僱員不給予通知而終止合約的情況

cases.caseName: Li Kwong Kiu v Wong Kin Fai t/a Sum Kee Engineering
cases.annotation: The most substantive authority on s.10(c), which permits an employee to terminate without notice where the employer has wilfully failed to pay wages when due on more than one occasion. The court provided a detailed analysis of what constitutes 'wilful' failure to pay wages, holding that repeated late payment of wages satisfying s.10(c) entitles the employee to leave immediately without notice and claim damages equivalent to wages in lieu of notice. The case also addressed the interplay between s.10 termination and the employee's entitlement to severance payment.

cases.caseName: De Nicolas v Lee Fung Lan t/a Beauty Queen Knitting Factory
cases.annotation: Applied s.10 in the context of constructive dismissal, holding that where the employer's conduct amounts to a fundamental breach of the employment contract, the employee is entitled to terminate without notice under s.10. The court considered the measure of damages available to an employee who terminates under s.10, confirming that the employee is entitled to wages in lieu of the notice period as if the employer had wrongfully dismissed without notice.

cases.caseName: Cheung Chi Yuk v Security Alliance Ltd
cases.annotation: An early authority on s.10(a) and s.10(b), which permit an employee to terminate without notice where the employee reasonably fears physical danger by violence or disease not contemplated by the contract. The court examined the scope of these grounds and their relationship to the common law right to refuse unsafe work, establishing that the employee's fear must be objectively reasonable in the circumstances.

cases.caseName: Yam Mei Ching v Tele-Art Electronics Ltd
cases.annotation: Addressed the boundary of s.10(aa), which permits an employee to terminate without notice where the employee has been subjected to ill-treatment by the employer and has become permanently unfit for the type of work performed. The court examined what constitutes 'permanent unfitness' within s.10(aa), distinguishing it from temporary incapacity, and considered whether the employee's medical evidence was sufficient to establish the ground.

sections.titleZh: 僱傭合約終止時的工資支付

cases.caseName: Secretary for Justice v Li Chi Leung
cases.annotation: The leading case on wage payment obligations under the Employment Ordinance. The court held that offences under ss.23 and 25 are continuing offences — the employer's obligation to pay wages arises from the time prescribed for payment and continues until actual payment is made. This means limitation periods run from the date of actual payment (or prosecution), not from the initial 7-day deadline. The case directly interprets the payment obligation and its interaction with s.63C criminal penalties.

cases.caseName: HKSAR v Kwan Wah Medicine Company Ltd
cases.annotation: A criminal appeal concerning five counts of wilfully failing to pay wages contrary to ss.23 and 63C. The court held that a private repayment agreement between employer and employee cannot convert unpaid wages into a civil debt and thereby defeat criminal prosecution — the criminal liability persists regardless. The judgment also affirmed the continuing offence doctrine from Li Chi Leung: the offence persists daily until wages are actually paid.

cases.caseName: Li Kwong Kiu v Wong Kin Fai t/a Chun Fai Transport
cases.annotation: Applied the wage payment deadline to determine whether the employer's failure to pay wages by the due date constituted a fundamental breach of the employment contract supporting constructive dismissal. The judgment contains extensive discussion including a full quotation of the Employment Ordinance Guidance Notes explaining the meaning of 'as soon as practicable' and the 7-day deadline. Payment more than 7 days late was held to constitute a breach going to the root of the contract.

cases.caseName: Leung Ka Lau v Hospital Authority
cases.annotation: The leading case on s.17. Public hospital doctors sued the Hospital Authority for failing to grant rest days when rostered on-call. The Court of Appeal extensively analysed what it means to 'grant' a rest day under s.17(1), whether being on non-resident call constitutes a deprivation of rest days, and the relationship between s.17 (granting rest days) and s.19 (requiring work on rest days). Split reasoning on whether on-call duties breach s.17 or s.19 — a key issue taken to the CFA.

cases.caseName: Yum Siu Wah v Auto Italia Limited
cases.annotation: A car sales executive claimed rest day compensation after his employment contract required overtime work. The court analysed whether s.17 requires formal written designation of rest days (held: no, compliance is a matter of substance) and whether a contractual clause requiring work 'from time to time without further remuneration' purported to extinguish the s.17 rest day right (held: it did not). Useful modern authority on how s.17 interacts with employment contract terms and s.70 (anti-contracting-out).

cases.caseName: Pun Pabitra v Wong Kan Hing
cases.annotation: A foreign domestic helper claimed wages for rest days never received. The court quotes s.17(1) and s.17(2) in full and clarifies that while s.17 confers the right to rest days, the Employment Ordinance does not prescribe that rest days must be paid. Distinguished between the right to a rest day (s.17) and the right to pay for working on a rest day (s.20). Useful early authority on the scope of s.17.

cases.caseName: Lubiano Nancy Almorin v Director of Immigration
cases.annotation: A foreign domestic helper challenged the 'Live-In Requirement' as a disproportionate interference with her right to rest days under ICESCR Article 7, arguing that s.17(1) was the domestic implementation of that international right. The Court of Appeal quoted s.17(1) in full and analysed whether the live-in requirement created a heightened risk of employers denying rest days. Contains substantive discussion of s.17 as implementing international rest day protections.

cases.caseName: Lui Tin Lung v Sun Po Yuen Noodle Shop & Cafe
cases.annotation: A noodle shop cook claimed rest day pay and other entitlements. The court quotes s.17 and applies it directly: the employee was entitled to 4 rest days per month under s.17(1), and examined whether working on rest days was at the employer's request (s.20(2)) to determine compensation. Practical analysis of how s.17 rest day entitlements interact with s.20 (work on rest days).

sections.titleEn: General provisions as to right to severance payment
sections.titleZh: 關於領取遣散費權利的一般條文

cases.caseName: Yan Kwok Tung v Kowloon Motor Bus Co Ltd
cases.annotation: A leading case on the construction of s.31B(2)(a) and s.31B(2)(c), addressing whether the 'place where the employee was so employed' refers to where the employee actually worked or where the employer could contractually require them to work. The court held that the physical location where the employee actually worked was relevant for determining a redundancy situation under s.31B(2). The case also examined the interplay between the s.31Q presumption of redundancy and the tribunal's duty to raise the issue of its own motion.

cases.caseName: Cheung Sau Ching v Fashion Garment Manufactory Ltd
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal considered whether employees were entitled to severance payment under s.31B(1)(b) when a factory closed temporarily for six weeks for refurbishment. The court examined the mechanics of s.31E lay-off (failure to provide 12 normal working days in any 4-week period) and its interaction with s.31B(1), holding that when the s.31E lay-off conditions are met, the employer becomes liable for severance payment. Significant for establishing how temporary business closures can trigger s.31B severance payment obligations.

cases.caseName: Gloria Weaving and Knitting Factory Ltd v Lam Hau Yee
cases.annotation: The court drew the important distinction in s.31B(1) between paragraph (a) (dismissal by reason of redundancy) and paragraph (b) (laid off within s.31E), holding that a claim based on lay-off under s.31B(1)(b) does not require the employee to first establish constructive dismissal. The case confirmed that s.31E preserves contract continuity during lay-off, and that resumption of work after a lay-off period does not constitute waiver defeating the s.31B entitlement.

cases.caseName: Fashion Art Garment Factory Ltd v Yeung Mau Ching
cases.annotation: The court provided a detailed analysis of how s.31B(1) creates the employer's liability in lay-off situations, explaining that the liability is expressly subject to the procedural requirements of s.31N (the employee must claim within the prescribed time) and s.31E (defining when a lay-off occurs). The court held that the employer's liability under s.31B(1) does not arise until the employee takes appropriate measures to assert entitlement under s.31N.

cases.caseName: Afia Worldwide Insurance v Ho Yuen-seung
cases.annotation: An early case directly applying s.31B(2)(c), addressing the meaning of 'redundancy situation' where the employer's requirements for employees to carry out work of a particular kind at a particular place diminished. The court set out the analytical framework: under s.31B(2)(c) read with s.31Q, the employer bears the burden of proving either that no redundancy situation existed, or that the dismissals were attributable to something other than redundancy.

cases.caseName: Yung Chi Keung v Protection of Wages on Insolvency Fund Board
cases.annotation: The CFA's definitive ruling on the interaction between the s.31G gross severance payment figure, s.31I deductions (MPF benefits), and the Cap 380 ex gratia payment cap. The CFA held that s.31I benefits should be deducted from the s.31G figure first, and only then should the statutory cap be applied — reversing the Commissioner's approach. This is the leading authority on how the s.31G calculation feeds into the Protection of Wages on Insolvency Fund framework.

cases.caseName: Yung Chi Keung v Protection of Wages on Insolvency Fund Board
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal extensively discussed how the s.31G severance payment figure serves as the basis for calculating the statutory cap under the Protection of Wages on Insolvency Ordinance. The court interpreted the legislature's intent in using the s.31G figure as a reference point, concluding it goes beyond merely setting a cap — it indicates the starting point for calculating the ex gratia payment. Subsequently reversed by the CFA on the order of deductions.

cases.caseName: Yung Chi Keung v Protection of Wages on Insolvency Fund Board
cases.annotation: The first-instance judicial review judgment that quotes the full text of s.31G(1) — the severance payment formula: two-thirds of last full month's wages (or two-thirds of the statutory maximum, whichever is less) for each year of service. The judgment provides a worked numerical example of the s.31G calculation and how it interacts with s.31I deductions, making it a practical reference for understanding the mechanics of the formula.

sections.titleEn: Severance payment to be reduced by amount of gratuities and benefits in certain cases
sections.titleZh: 在某些情況下，遣散費須扣除酬金及利益或權益的款額

cases.caseName: Yung Chi Keung v Protection of Wages on Insolvency Fund Board
cases.annotation: The leading CFA authority on the operation of s.31I. The Court held that s.31I benefits (MPF employer contributions, occupational retirement scheme payments, gratuities) must be deducted from the gross severance payment calculated under s.31G before applying any statutory cap — not after. This establishes that s.31I operates to reduce the employee's severance payment entitlement itself (producing a 'net' figure), rather than merely reducing the amount ultimately paid out.

cases.caseName: Yung Chi Keung v Protection of Wages on Insolvency Fund Board
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal (reversed by the CFA in [2016] HKCFA 32) held that s.31I deductions should be applied after the statutory cap, not before. Although overturned, the judgment contains detailed analysis of how s.31I operates as a reduction mechanism, including the characterisation of s.31I benefits as 'part-payment' of the employee's severance entitlement. The CA's reasoning on whether s.31I reduces the entitlement or the amount payable remains instructive for understanding the competing interpretations.

cases.caseName: Yan Kwok Tung v Kai Tak Construction Material Co Ltd
cases.annotation: An early authority on s.31I addressing whether a tribunal is obliged to inquire of its own motion whether employees had received provident fund payments that would reduce their severance payment. The court established that s.31I requires severance payments to be reduced by any provident fund payment received, and discussed the procedural obligation on tribunals to consider s.31I deductions even where not raised by the parties.

sections.titleEn: General provisions as to employee's right to long service payment
sections.titleZh: 僱員領取長期服務金權利的一般條文

cases.caseName: Archer v Hong Kong Channel Ltd
cases.annotation: The leading CFA authority on s.31R. The Court addressed the meaning of 'relevant date' in s.31R(1) for computing the qualifying period of not less than 5 years' service. Litton PJ held that the relevant date is the date on which the employee's employment is actually terminated (not the date notice is given), and that the qualifying period must be completed by that date. This interpretation resolved conflicting lower court authorities on how to calculate the 5-year threshold.

cases.caseName: Thomas Vincent v South China Morning Post Publishers Ltd
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal provided the most comprehensive judicial overview of the s.31R long service payment scheme, setting out how it interacts with the s.32K valid reason framework. The court confirmed that an employee dismissed without a valid reason under s.32K who has completed 5 years' service is entitled to long service payment under s.31R(1)(a)(ii) (dismissal other than by reason of redundancy and other than under s.9). The judgment systematically maps the relationship between Part VA (long service payment) and Part VIA (employment protection).

cases.caseName: Chak Chong Chi v Maxim's Caterers Ltd
cases.annotation: Addressed the interplay between s.31R and s.31S (disqualification from long service payment). The court examined whether an employee who resigned voluntarily was entitled to long service payment under s.31R(1)(b) (termination by reason of permanent unfitness certified by a medical practitioner), and considered the circumstances in which s.31S operates to deny long service payment where the employee has been guilty of misconduct.

cases.caseName: Allidem Mae G. Basa v Kwong Si Lin t/a Kwong Si Lin
cases.annotation: A detailed exposition of the full s.31R statutory scheme, setting out all the qualifying conditions for long service payment: (i) employment under a continuous contract for not less than 5 years; (ii) termination falling within one of the specified grounds in s.31R(1)(a)-(d) (dismissal not by reason of redundancy, resignation on medical grounds, death, retirement at age 65, or employer-initiated early retirement). The court also explained how the calculation formula in s.31V operates and its relationship to the s.31I reduction mechanism.

cases.caseName: Leung Wan Kee Shipyard Ltd v Tang Yuen Sum
cases.annotation: Addressed the continuous contract requirement under s.31R(1), which requires the employee to have been employed under a 'continuous contract' (as defined in s.6A) for not less than 5 years. The court considered what constitutes continuous service for the purposes of s.31R and how interruptions in employment affect the calculation of the qualifying period.

cases.caseName: Ng On Fook v Chiaphua Extrusions Ltd
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal directly addressed the s.31V(1)(b) calculation method for non-monthly-rated employees (18 days' wages from the last 30 normal working days). The key holding is that overtime pay constituting a regular part of wages must be included in the wage base for calculating long service payment. The court rejected the employer's argument for a 12-month average overtime figure, affirming the employee's right to use the 18 highest-earning days.

cases.caseName: Lee Hung Chiu Philip v Becton Dickinson Asia Limited
cases.annotation: Applies the s.31V(1)(a) formula in detail for a monthly-rated employee dismissed after approximately 12 years. The court quotes the two-thirds-of-last-full-month's-wages formula (capped at two-thirds of $22,500) and works through the arithmetic. Also addresses the s.31Y offset, where the employer sought to reduce the long service payment by a Singaporean CPF benefit analogous to MPF.

cases.caseName: Au Lung On v Apexgain Investments Ltd t/a Lucky House Seafood Restaurant
cases.annotation: Provides a practical worked example of both calculation methods under s.31V for monthly-rated employees: (i) two-thirds of the last full month's wages, and (ii) two-thirds of the average wages over the preceding 12 months. The court shows both calculations numerically, demonstrating how the two methods yield different results and how the pro rata calculation for incomplete years of service works in practice.

cases.caseName: Mohammad Khurshid Qazi v Karbhari Jal Nadirshaw t/a Jal N. Karbhari & Co
cases.annotation: Quotes s.31V(1) in full (including both limbs (a) and (b)) and applies the calculation formula to determine long service payment for a solicitor's clerk after 12 years of service. The judgment works through the s.31Y MPF offset, ultimately concluding the employer was entitled to set off MPF contributions against the long service payment — a practical example of how the calculated amount is modified by the offset regime.

cases.caseName: Li Hon Man & Chan Lai Ha v Crystal Knitters Limited
cases.annotation: The most directly relevant authority on s.33(4B), which prohibits an employer from terminating employment under s.6 or s.7 on any sickness day on which sickness allowance is payable. The court held that the s.33(4B) prohibition applies only to lawful terminations by notice (s.6) or payment in lieu (s.7), and does not cover wrongful dismissals. The judgment also considered claims under s.33(4BA)(b) (compensation equal to 7 days' wages for dismissal during sick leave) and s.33(4C) (sickness allowance for the remaining sick leave period after dismissal).

cases.caseName: Karchoud Leila Bent Mohamed v The Incorporated Trustees of the Islamic Community Fund of Hong Kong
cases.annotation: Considered the s.33(4B) protection against dismissal during sick leave in the context of a broader unreasonable dismissal claim under s.32P. The court found that the s.33(4B) argument provided only 'slender support' for compensation where the dismissal was for genuine operational reasons unrelated to the sick leave. The judgment also examined s.33(4BA) sickness allowance calculation, finding the employer had already paid more than the statutory entitlement.

cases.caseName: So Yuet Sheung v Link Step Limited
cases.annotation: Directly interprets s.12(1)'s 26-week continuous contract requirement for maternity leave entitlement. The court examined the interplay between s.12 (right to leave) and s.14 (right to pay), clarifying that the qualifying periods differ — s.12(1) requires 26 weeks of continuous employment for the right to maternity leave, while s.14(2)(a) requires 40 weeks for maternity leave pay. The case addressed how continuity of the employment contract is assessed when work arrangements change mid-employment from permanent piecework to casual work.

cases.caseName: Hong Kong Ming Wah Shipping Co Ltd v Sun Min
cases.annotation: The highest authority on the scope of s.15(1). The CFA confirmed that s.15(1)(a) prohibits all forms of termination by the employer during the protected pregnancy period — whether lawful under the contract or wrongful — with the sole exception of summary dismissal for genuine misconduct under s.9. A forced transfer to a different company, even within the same corporate group, constituted termination of the continuous contract and was prohibited. The protection is absolute during the maternity period.

cases.caseName: Sun Min v Hong Kong Ming Wah Shipping Co Ltd
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal upheld the CFI's finding that the forced transfer of a pregnant employee to a subsidiary company outside Hong Kong amounted to a termination prohibited by s.15. The court held that the employer's lack of awareness of the pregnancy at the time of the transfer decision was irrelevant to a compensation claim under s.15 — the prohibition is strict and does not depend on the employer's knowledge. The court also rejected the argument that s.15(4)'s criminal sanction required a narrow construction favouring the employer.

cases.caseName: Sun Min v Hong Kong Ming Wah Shipping Co Ltd
cases.annotation: The first instance decision in the Sun Min litigation. Deputy Judge Poon provided a detailed exposition of the s.15 statutory scheme, including the interplay between the pregnancy notice requirement (s.12(4)), the prohibition on termination (s.15(1)), the reverse burden of proof under s.15(1B), and the compensation remedies under s.15(2) (one month's wages plus maternity leave pay). The employer's purported transfer of a pregnant employee to a subsidiary was held to constitute termination in contravention of s.15(1).

cases.caseName: HKSAR v S. Space Design (HK) Co Ltd
cases.annotation: A criminal appeal arising from conviction under ss.15(1) and 15(4) for terminating a pregnant employee after she gave notice of maternity leave. The employer purported to summarily dismiss for misconduct (relying on the s.9 exception), but the magistrate found the alleged misconduct unproven and convicted. The CFI confirmed that the court will look behind a purported s.9 summary dismissal to determine whether genuine misconduct existed, and that a sham dismissal disguised as s.9 will attract criminal liability under s.15(4).

cases.caseName: Leung Ka Lau v Hospital Authority
cases.annotation: Part of the leading Hospital Authority doctors' litigation on s.39. The Court of Appeal confirmed the CFA's ruling that doctors are entitled to statutory holidays under s.39 and that in default of being granted such holidays, they are entitled to damages assessed at a full day's wages per missed holiday. The case addresses the damages remedy for breach of s.39 in the context of a major institutional employer with complex rostering arrangements.

cases.caseName: Leung Ka Lau v Hospital Authority
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal certified key s.39 questions for the CFA: whether a doctor rostered on non-resident call on a statutory holiday but not actually called to work has been 'deprived' of that holiday, and how damages for breach of s.39 should be computed. These were certified as questions of great general or public importance, establishing s.39 interpretation as a significant area of employment law.

cases.caseName: Leung Ka Lau v Hospital Authority
cases.annotation: The first instance decision in the Hospital Authority doctors' litigation. The court set out the relevant provisions of s.39: s.39(1) requires employers to grant 12 statutory holidays per year, and s.39(2) permits employers to designate an alternative holiday by written or oral notice. The judgment interprets the statutory framework for holiday entitlement alongside s.17 (rest days), providing a comprehensive analysis of the mechanics of s.39 compliance.

cases.caseName: HKSAR v Yu Shi Tiancheng Enterprise Ltd
cases.annotation: A criminal prosecution where the employer was convicted on 8 charges of failing to grant statutory holidays to cleaning workers contrary to s.39. The employees had only one rest day per month, which was sometimes replaced by pay in lieu. The case illustrates the criminal enforcement dimension of s.39 and establishes that substituting pay for holidays does not satisfy the statutory obligation to grant time off.

cases.caseName: Chan Lok Mei v Sze Chi Sing t/a Kwun Tong St Agnes English Kindergarten
cases.annotation: A foundational case on s.41AA(1) and (2), interpreting the 12-month continuous contract requirement for annual leave entitlement. The court held that even on a fixed-term contract (school year), employees who completed 12 months' service were entitled to at least 7 days' annual leave with pay under s.41AA(2). The judgment also discusses the interaction between s.41AA and s.41D (pro rata annual leave pay on termination).

cases.caseName: Wu Kam Ming v Hung Tat Warehouse, Transportation and Shipping Co Ltd
cases.annotation: The leading interpretation of s.41AA(4), which requires an employer to give at least 14 days' written notice when designating annual leave dates. The court held that s.41AA(4) applies only when the employer unilaterally designates leave dates, not when the employee requests leave — the legislative intent was not to give employers the sole right to determine leave timing while stripping employees of that right.

cases.caseName: Annual leave employer obligation case
cases.annotation: Directly interprets s.41AA(5)(a) and s.41AA(8)(a), analysing the employer's obligation to grant annual leave before the expiry of 12 months after the end of the leave year, and the employee's remedy when the employer fails — the employee may elect to receive annual leave pay as compensation or take the leave. Provides substantive judicial analysis of the mechanics and remedies under s.41AA.

sections.titleEn: Reasons for the dismissal or the variation of the terms of the contract of employment
sections.titleZh: 解僱或更改僱傭合約條款的理由

cases.caseName: Vincent v South China Morning Post Publishers Ltd
cases.annotation: The leading Court of Appeal authority on s.32K. The Court held that once an employer proves dismissal was by reason of one of the five facts listed in s.32K (conduct, capability, redundancy, illegality, or other reason of substance), the statutory presumption in s.32A(2) is rebutted without any additional discretionary consideration as to whether it was reasonable to dismiss or whether procedural fairness was observed. Yuen JA held that the word 'valid' in s.32K means only the five enumerated reasons are accepted — all other reasons, however legitimate, are insufficient. The s.32K test is purely factual (was the stated reason the true reason?) rather than evaluative.

cases.caseName: Blakeney-Williams v Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd
cases.annotation: Building on Vincent, the Court of Appeal provided the most detailed analysis of s.32K in a mass employment dispute involving Cathay Pacific pilots. The Court clarified that 'conduct' under s.32K(a) is not limited to misconduct (which is dealt with separately under s.9), and that the question is not whether the employer acted reasonably in treating the conduct as sufficient reason for dismissal. It suffices if the reason given is the true reason, is not a pretext, is not trifling, and is relevant to the question whether to dismiss.

cases.caseName: Le Thi Bich Thuy Kitty v Sheraton International (Hong Kong) Ltd
cases.annotation: Lam J clarified that s.32K and summary dismissal under s.9 are distinct legal concepts that should not be conflated. Section 32K defines 'valid reasons' for dismissal under Part VIA employment protection, whereas s.9 governs summary dismissal for cause. The Court held that s.32K has no bearing on summary dismissal since s.32B(1)(a) expressly excludes summary dismissals from Part VIA. A useful authority for understanding the boundary between Part VIA employment protection and common law/statutory dismissal.

cases.caseName: Cheung Chi Keung v Hospital Authority
cases.annotation: Applying the Vincent interpretation of s.32K, Deputy Judge To held that once a case of termination by reason of the employee's conduct under s.32K is made out, the statutory presumption is rebutted without any need to assess whether the termination was justified or proportionate. The case confirms that procedural fairness (such as following a formal disciplinary process) is not a prerequisite for establishing a valid reason under s.32K.

sections.titleZh: 復職及再次聘用的命令

cases.caseName: Secretary for Justice v Sing Pao Newspaper Management Limited
cases.annotation: The Court of Appeal reviewed manifestly inadequate fines totalling $4,200 for 11 offences under s.63C for late payment of wages. The judgment quotes s.63C in full, discusses the 2006 legislative increase in penalties (from $200,000/1 year to $350,000/3 years), and establishes sentencing principles for wage payment offences. Likely the leading appellate authority on sentencing for s.63C offences.

cases.caseName: HKSAR v Li Fung Ching Catherine
cases.annotation: CFA-level authority on s.63C read with s.64B(1) (director liability). A company director was convicted on 11 summonses for non-payment of wages because the company deliberately failed to pay, choosing to meet other operating expenses instead. The CFA held this was 'without reasonable excuse.' The highest-level authority on the interaction between s.63C and director liability under s.64B.

cases.caseName: HKSAR v Wong Yuk-tung
cases.annotation: Directly considers whether 'without reasonable excuse' in s.63C places a persuasive burden on the defendant or merely an evidential one. Two company directors were convicted of three offences each for failing to pay wages. Essential for understanding the burden of proof for the 'reasonable excuse' element of s.63C.

cases.caseName: HKSAR v Lor Wai Por
cases.annotation: Addresses who qualifies as an 'employer' for the purposes of s.63C and the related s.65(1) compensation order. The appellant was a sole proprietor who incorporated his business but continued to manage it personally. Analyses whether an individual director can be personally liable as an 'employer' under s.63C (primary liability) versus derivative director liability via s.64B(1).

cases.caseName: Secretary for Justice v Li Chi Leung t/a Transmate Service Co.
cases.annotation: Addresses whether offences under ss.23 and 25 (penalised by s.63C) are continuing offences for the purpose of the 6-month limitation period under s.26 of the Magistrates Ordinance. Discusses the legislative purpose of s.63C — to protect employees from unscrupulous employers by criminalising wilful delay in paying wages. Important for understanding prosecution time limits.

sections.titleZh: 訂立本條例不適用的合約條款

cases.caseName: Ren Ruiwei & Others v Wanchai Sun Kwong Restaurant Ltd
cases.annotation: The leading case on s.70. A restaurant's employment contract required employees to agree at hiring to work on 2 of 4 rest days per month ('buying rest days'). The Court of Appeal held this contractual term 'purported to extinguish or reduce' the employee's rest day entitlement under s.17 and was therefore void under s.70. Most thorough judicial treatment of s.70 — extensive analysis of whether s.70 applies to pre-contractual agreements about rest days.

cases.caseName: HKSAR v Physical Health Centre Hong Kong Ltd
cases.annotation: The employer was convicted of non-payment of statutory holiday pay and sought leave to appeal to the CFA on whether estoppel by convention could override s.70. The court refused, holding that s.70's wording is 'clear and unequivocal' — if a doctrine (including estoppel) alters the employment relationship so as to reduce or extinguish an employee's statutory rights, s.70 renders the variation void. Notable for applying s.70 in a criminal prosecution context.

cases.caseName: Yum Siu Wah v Auto Italia Ltd
cases.annotation: Provides a nuanced analysis of s.70: it is only invoked if a contractual clause, properly construed, purports to extinguish or reduce a statutory right — the test is one of substance based on the terms of the clause, not its post-contractual performance. A clause merely defining working hours that did not on its face deprive the claimant of rest days did not trigger s.70.

cases.caseName: Cheung Sau Ching & Others v Fashion Garment Manufactory Ltd
cases.annotation: An early and important case on s.70. A garment factory closed and employees accepted an agreement giving them less than their statutory entitlements for lay-off/severance. The court found the employees believed they were receiving minimum legal rights but the agreement reduced their statutory benefits. Applied s.70 to void the agreement as it reduced rights under s.31E.

cases.caseName: Wong Yin Mui Sandy v Newport May (Administratrix)
cases.annotation: A personal assistant claimed $441,000 under a cheque issued as severance payment. The estate argued the agreement was void under s.70. The court held s.70 did NOT apply because the agreement exceeded the statutory minimum — s.70 only restricts terms that reduce or extinguish statutory rights, not terms that provide more generous benefits. Important for defining the outer boundary of s.70.

sections.titleEn: Employment not to be terminated, etc. by reason of fact that employee gave evidence, etc.
sections.titleZh: 不得以僱員曾在根據本條例進行的法律程序中作供等理由而終止僱用及其他情況

cases.caseName: Hui King Fai v The Hong Kong Council of Social Service
cases.annotation: The leading case on the substantive application of s.72B(1). The court analysed the two-limb test under s.32A(1)(c)(i) for claims based on dismissal in contravention of s.72B(1): (i) the dismissal was without a valid reason under s.32K, and (ii) it was 'by reason of' the employee having given evidence in Employment Ordinance proceedings. The court held that once the employee shows she falls within s.72B, the burden shifts to the employer to prove a valid reason. The judgment also addresses the 12-month temporal requirement under s.32A(5)(b) and the quantification of s.32P compensation.

cases.caseName: HKSAR v Penta-Ocean Construction Co Ltd
cases.annotation: A criminal prosecution under s.72B(1)(b) (read with s.63A) where the employer was charged with terminating an employee by reason of the employee having reported wage and MPF irregularities to a public officer (Labour Department). After a 14-day trial the summons was dismissed. The case illustrates the criminal enforcement dimension of s.72B and the practical difficulties in proving that the reason for dismissal was the employee's whistleblowing activity.
